'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-12 10:00:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 31: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(11 inline comments)

Hi Again Sumit,

first of all apologies for keeping you wait on this patch.
In the code I have a few more questions on some aspects of the plugin class I did not notice before.

I also think we can easily make an effort to address the db ineffiency on firewall rule list loading.

Even if I reckon this is a very good patch, there are stilll two bits I'm not comfortable with; I hope you can shed some light on them.

The first is the 'audited' attribute; I understand what it does and why it's there. However, it's not used by either driver or agent. My preference would be add it only when it would be used. If you're concerned about the need for a db migration, and extra inconvenciences for the db classes, could you at list consider making it a hidden attribute at the moment?

The second is the 'shared' attributes; they're everywhere and you already explained me what you wanted to achieve with them. I struggle a bit to understand the concept of a 'shared' firewall, whereas it is ok for me on policies and rules. However, I do not see how the sharing is handled so far. For instance I would expect any tenant to be able to associate a shared policy to its firewall.
Perhaps it's just me missing something.

The third is the association between a firewall and a router.
It is not mandated in the API, but it looks like the agent instead applies the firewall policies to every router for a given tenant.
Is this model the correct one? I am not sure. A tenant might have any arbitrary L2/L3 topology with different requirements, and it is likely that the rules which apply for a rotuer do not apply to another router. For instance I know of some real deployments where tenants can decide whether to uplink a router on a corporate network or on an external network - in that case the policies to apply are likely to be different.
I drop the question here, aware of the rage which might raise: do we want to add a router_id to the firewall?

To quickly address this questions, find me on IRC. I will be on the usual channels the whole day."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-12 16:02:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 31:

Hi Salvatore,

Thanks again for your detailed review. Let me try to address the three points you raised here, and then I will post a follow up patch for the inline comments.

'audited' attribute - I was thinking that the setting of this attribute is handled by the user (via create/update), and we do not need do anything special for this. Providing a way for the user to flag that a policy is audited or not might be enough. That said, I could add processing to automatically set the attribute to false each time the firewall_policy's rules are changed. This will ensure that any changes to a currently audited firewall_policy would have to be explicitly audited again (by updating this attribute). Would that be acceptable?

'shared' attribute - yes, it is currently not very functional in the context of the firewall resource. My proposal is that we have a sort of a 'user' attribute to achieve this, however that will not be in this patch. Would you prefer that I make this attribute hidden?

Association between a firewall and a router - yes, in the current state of the implementation the agent applies the firewall policy to every router for a given tenant. This will change once we introduce the service insertion semantics, at which point, and based on the insertion mode, the right insertion point (like the router_id you suggest) can be used to more selectively insert the firewall.

Please let me know if the above address your concerns."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-12 17:32:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 31:

Sumit,

- on 'audited': from your description it is pretty much a descriptive field. The user flags it up or down but nothing changes actually in the backend. I remember we envisioned 'audited' as something which would mark a rule in a way that backends would notify, for instance, security admins when it was hit.
If this will be supported in the future by some drivers, let's introduce this capability in the future. I think we should be able to develop driver-specific extensions.
- on 'shared': if the implementation of the related use case has been deferred, let's either remove the attirbute or ensure it is at least hidden in the api (in the latter case please put a node in the code to explain why it's hidden)
- on router mapping: I am a not sure about the strategy of associating the firewall with all the routers of a tenant. Regardless of how you can associate a firewall to quantum resources, it seems here we have implemented something that integrates very well with routers and l3 agents.
adding a router_id attribute to the firewall will put a dent in future work on insertion of services in l2/l3 topologies, building advanced chain of services, and making unicorns cry tears of joy; perhaps what we could do is to add an action to the router resource to associate it with a firewall:

- something like
PUT /routers/<router-id>/set_firewall

I think this will be consistent with future development when you can insert a firewall at various levels."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-12 20:37:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 31:

Thanks again Salvatore. 

'audited' - I think there is some disconnect on what this attribute is for. Per our spec, this attribute is meant to capture the audit status of the policy - paraphrasing the spec - "Typically, there would exist a process of auditing a Firewall Policy against specific compliance requirements, only after which it would be relevant to commit the Firewall Policy to a logical Firewall instance…The rules have to be first added to a Firewall Policy and the Firewall Policy has to be reapplied for the rules to take effect. This two-step process allows the Firewall Policy to be audited after the new rules are added and before the policy is reapplied to a Firewall."
I believe the auditing requirement you are referring to is the counters/logs for rules. This has been thought of but it is a fairly large feature in itself, so it won't be a part of this patch.

'shared' - I will hide it.

'router_id' - thanks for your suggestion on adding an operation. Let me think a little more on this. That said, whatever we do to accommodate this use case will end up impacting all three patches (API, Agent and Driver). My thinking is that these patches already represent a significantly large amount of code and features to review. Given that a patch for adding the router_id association could be self-contained patch (once these patches get merged), my preference would be to treat it as a separate feature/patch (addressed as a high priority). Would that be acceptable to you?'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-12 20:42:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 31:

deal on audited. Sorry I misunderstood the purpose. I thought the driver was supposed to do something different to treat an audited policy.

deal on shared too

on association with router_id, my only concern is that delaying will leave technical debt to address during H-3 (suprisingly it's the second time in a hours I use this term - that must because we're close to the deadline!)

I am pretty sure you will address it, but I would like to hear first the opinion of the other core devs reviewing this patch."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-12 21:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 31:

Thanks for the deals! :-)

Just to put the router_id association feature into perspective (and for the benefit of other reviewers as well), this was not considered to be in the scope of the original blueprint for this particular patch since it was thought to be a separate feature. Of course, I am not averse to expanding the scope, but just wanted to reiterate the original plan and thinking.'}, {'account_id': 7752, 'date': '2013-07-13 23:06:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 31:

Sumit/Salvatore,

Regarding "adding a router_id attribute to the firewall ...", I do not see how router_id fits into a firewall. First co-existence of firewall and L3 agent is specific to the way IPTables driver is being implemented. I do not see how a router_id in a firewall will make sense in L2 insertion or in some L3 insertion modes as well.

Also, we have to look at long term goal. Immediately after we are done with H2 code commit, we will be implementing 'zones'. Zones will be collection of interfaces (or networks or something else) that would indirectly point us to the router ID in case of IPTables driver. For other firewall drivers, zones will make more sense (and not router-id).

Application of firewall rules on all routers is a side-effect of not implementing zones in the first release. I would say that we should not add router-id to firewall resource as it would not make sense (or not used)  in future releases.

Thanks,
-Rajesh Mohan'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-14 19:48:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 32.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-14 19:51:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 31: (11 inline comments)

Looks OK now. No further comments for me.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-26 21:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 49: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(9 inline comments)

Comments are mostly nits or other stupid things.

I have one question which I would like to seek your advice on.
This API does port ranges in a way different from security groups (see comment inline). We should strive for consistency, unless there is a very good reason for not being consistent. I guess you have such reason, but I must have missed it as it might be buried in one of the comments in the previous 48 patchsets.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-26 21:43:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 49: No score

sorry I should have not +1 as at least the change in the migration is needed.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-26 22:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 50.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-26 22:58:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 50:

Thanks Salvatore for your review again. On the question regarding the port range, I am paraphrasing from my earlier responses -

Patch 39, neutron/db/firewall/firewall_db.py L51
We needed a way to represent, both a single port, and also a port range. We decided to follow the well understood/established convention used by Iptables to use the following format: Single port: String or Integer, e.g. 8800 Port range: "p1:p2" where 0 < int(p1) <= int(p2) < 65535. The up side of this approach is that we don't have to do additional processing before passing it to the reference Iptables implementation, and also that this convention is familiar to operators.

Patch 40, neutron/db/firewall/firewall_db.py L51
Yes, as I mentioned in my earlier comment in patch 39, talking to some of the vendors it seemed that this format for port/range was generally more acceptable. The reason for adopting this convention is not because it is less work to translate in code. To reiterate, it follows an established convention. I appreciate the concern to be consistent, and in this case I think we should be consistent with conventions in the firewall world not necessarily how it's done in security groups.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-07-26 23:16:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 49: (9 inline comments)

commit_message:
Firewall as a Service (FWaaS) APIs and DB Model

Implements: blueprint quantum-fwaas

blueprint: quantum-fwaas-plugin

This is the first iteration of the FWaaS implementation and
is geared towards implementing the model that will be
required to at least address the reference implementation.

This iteration will not include implementation of the following
features:
* grouping or dynamic objects
* application/service objects

Change-Id: I57a62d6e9d3f1e6c4dd44cd5c745710a3d9e488e

commit_message:
Merge v1_1's base module into main base module

This class was forked from novaclient.base when adding v1.1 support and
and because v1.0 is no longer supported it can be merged again.

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: I3113eff522a9dc280f48053001afa9e1a0cad3e3

commit_message:
Use current username as default

Instead of russelb.  I mean, it's the user's fault they aren't
russelb, but I think this change follows the robustness principle.

Change-Id: I5a5b09836840220540980e6d0eb0e4d324dc2678

commit_message:
Add user quota client API support

    Implements blueprint user-quota-related-client-api

    This patch adds user arguments to the following subcommands:
        * quota-show
        * quota-update
        * quota-delete

Change-Id: I6556de366a758f7550e9b26357f231666caae419

"}, {'created': '2013-06-29 08:06:06.000000000', 'message': 'Move multi-threading code to a library.

This patch extracts the multi-threading code from bin/swift into
swiftclient/multithreading and adds tests.  In particular, this new way
of doing it (with a context manager) will prevent non-daemonic threads
from wedging the process when unexpected exceptions happen.

I enabled reporting of which lines, specifically, are not covered by
unit tests.

This patch includes a drive-by fix for uploading a segmented file with
--use-slo when that object already exists.  A key of "name" was used
instead of "path", raising KeyError.

There's also another drive-by fix for uploading segmented objects with
--use-slo.  Commit 874e0e4427b80e1b15b74a1557b73ba9d61443ca regressed
this by removing the capturing of thread-worker results in
QueueFunctionThread.run().  This patch restores that functionality and
the feature (uploading SLO objects).

Change-Id: I0b4f677e4a734e83d1a25088d9a74f7d46384e53

commit_message:
Move multi-threading code to a library.

This patch extracts the multi-threading code from bin/swift into
swiftclient/multithreading and adds tests.  In particular, this new way
of doing it (with context managers) will prevent non-daemonic threads
from wedging the process when unexpected exceptions happen.

I enabled reporting of which lines, specifically, are not covered by
unit tests (added -m option to "coverage report" in .unittests).

This patch includes a drive-by fix for uploading a segmented file with
--use-slo when that object already exists.  A key of "name" was used
instead of "path", raising KeyError.

There's also another drive-by fix for uploading segmented objects with
--use-slo.  Commit 874e0e4427b80e1b15b74a1557b73ba9d61443ca regressed
this by removing the capturing of thread-worker results in
QueueFunctionThread.run().  This patch restores that functionality and
the feature (uploading SLO objects).

Change-Id: I0b4f677e4a734e83d1a25088d9a74f7d46384e53

commit_message:
Allow gateway address to be unset for an existing subnet

Validation of the gateway IP address was taken place even
if the gateway IP was set to None; this was causing an
AddrFormatError exception to be raised by method
'_validate_gw_out_of_pools'. With this change we skip
the validation in case the gateway is set to None.

Fixes bug #1178273

Change-Id: Ib84378a4fd2cefdbbcacce695abbfaf82c647dd3
(cherry picked from commit 40a5853970cdd1555dfb5ebce81c6babf2e445da)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-29 21:40:05.000000000', 'message': 'Fix DHCP agent to work with latest dnsmasq

The latest dnsmasq no longer accepts hostnames which begin with a number. This
affects Fedora 19 right now, and will mean Fedora 19 will not work with Neutron
DHCP. dnsmasq should work with hostnames beginning with a number (RFC 1123 says
this is valid), but until this is fixed, many users will be left unable to use
Fedora 19 with Neutron.

This patch adds a "host-" prefix to each hostname entry generated by the DHCP
agent. This fixes the issue in Neutron.

Fixes bug 1204125

Change-Id: I0e29ec033969c3fb958ed3a12b8962b73b0e3d94
(cherry picked from commit acebf769a41a9a55cdc6789bf4962ea64cf87773)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix DHCP agent to work with latest dnsmasq

The latest dnsmasq no longer accepts hostnames which begin with a number. This
affects Fedora 19 right now, and will mean Fedora 19 will not work with Neutron
DHCP. dnsmasq should work with hostnames beginning with a number (RFC 1123 says
this is valid), but until this is fixed, many users will be left unable to use
Fedora 19 with Neutron.

This patch adds a "host-" prefix to each hostname entry generated by the DHCP
agent. This fixes the issue in Neutron.

Fixes bug 1204125

Change-Id: I0e29ec033969c3fb958ed3a12b8962b73b0e3d94
(cherry picked from commit acebf769a41a9a55cdc6789bf4962ea64cf87773)

[{'created': '2013-07-29 21:42:19.000000000', 'message': "do not raise exception on ip address recycle operation

Currenty a exception will raise on ip address recycle operation if the ip
address doesn't belong to any allocation pool which will make user unable
to update port, even worse it will make user unable to create new port.
So do not raise exception if the ip address to be recycled doesn't belong
to any allocation, just delete it from the ip allocation table.

fixes bug 1201692

commit_message:
do not raise exception on ip address recycle operation

Currenty a exception will raise on ip address recycle operation if the ip
address doesn't belong to any allocation pool which will make user unable
to update port, even worse it will make user unable to create new port.
So do not raise exception if the ip address to be recycled doesn't belong
to any allocation, just delete it from the ip allocation table.

fixes bug 1201692

Change-Id: Icfbded5158f1f4043f69bb1463fd4c830c9714a9
(cherry picked from commit d6cddd430c237c9496a97978070e6891d4625d00)

commit_message:
Allow v1 client to list all users' images

Add a '--all-tenants' option to the image-list command.  This adds
'is_public=None' to the query string passed to the server, and for an
admin user results in a listing of all images present on the server
irrespective of owner or public values.

Addresses bug 1201787.

Change-Id: I38dd0752a31ebea84f16b786d205e82eba1a96bc

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 11:03:03.000000000', 'message': "Add v1 client side owner based filtering

Add the --owner option to the v1 client's image-list command to support
filtering images based on the owner (tenand id).

Allows administrators to more easily list a particular user's images.

Note that this is far less efficient than v2 server-side owner based filtering.

Addresses bug 1201765.

Change-Id: I4ffa522b96c91e659c87f5452f2f1f44e47e806b

commit_message:
Add v1 client side owner based filtering

Add the --owner option to the v1 client's image-list command to support
filtering images based on the owner (tenant id).

Allows administrators to more easily list a particular user's images.

Note that this is far less efficient than v2 server-side owner based filtering.

Addresses bug 1201765.

Change-Id: I4ffa522b96c91e659c87f5452f2f1f44e47e806b

Bug 1206512

'}]
commit_message:
Do not allow duplication of (svc_type, provider) pairs

Bug 1206512

Fail at startup if the tuple consistuted by service type and provider
name is specified multiple times in neutron configuration.
This prevents ambiguity in driver selection, as different drivers
might be specified for same (svc_type, provider) pair.

Change-Id: Icfa8d83f2fafe2d0b506770e27fb0a1a68f6030d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-02 22:44:03.000000000', 'message': 'solidfire: Add ability to override account prefix

The SolidFire account is created with a prefix based on the hostname
of the host running cinder-volume. This prevents cinder-volume from
being run in an active/active setup.

This patch introduces a new configuration option sf_account_prefix
to override the prefix used when a SolidFire account is created.

If sf_account_prefix is empty, no prefix will be added to
the SolidFire account name when created.

The default value is still the hostname.

Change-Id: I3b974789ea3e749cc8696b69754023ad76155179
Fixes: bug #1179671
(cherry picked from commit f9fd91e05e7d8d4a7d3a4659ba3c0ebd483732e1)
'}]
commit_message:
solidfire: Add ability to override account prefix

The SolidFire account is created with a prefix based on the hostname
of the host running cinder-volume. This prevents cinder-volume from
being run in an active/active setup.

This patch introduces a new configuration option sf_account_prefix
to override the prefix used when a SolidFire account is created.

If sf_account_prefix is empty, no prefix will be added to
the SolidFire account name when created.

The default value is still the hostname.

Change-Id: I3b974789ea3e749cc8696b69754023ad76155179
Fixes: bug #1179671
(cherry picked from commit f9fd91e05e7d8d4a7d3a4659ba3c0ebd483732e1)

commit_message:
Update I18N code style

Change: msg = _("Missing parameter: %s") % ("flavor",)
to : msg = _("Missing parameter: %s") % ("flavor")

No need to add comma for flavor.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-02 17:08:02.000000000', 'message': 'Make physical resource names unique based upon stack name

Some templates use the same resource name when registering with
nova.  Nova will not allow mulitple resource names to register
with the same name in all cases, and in those it does, it often
becomes confused (in the case of EIP).  This patch creates a
dot notation

For the LB test, an example of the resources would be:
teststack.LoadBalancer.LB_instance
teststack.DatabaseServer.MySqlDatabaseServer
teststack.WikiServerOne

Change-Id: I14f4551feb41c7f98caa30dd98f997da6d00c467
Signed-off-by: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2012-12-02 17:08:02.000000000', 'message': 'Make physical resource names unique based upon stack name

Fixes Issue #160

Signed-off-by: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Make physical resource names unique based upon stack name

Some templates use the same resource name when registering with
nova.  Nova will not allow mulitple resource names to register
with the same name in all cases, and in those it does, it often
becomes confused (in the case of EIP).  This patch creates a
dot notation

For the LB test, an example of the resources would be:
teststack.LoadBalancer.LB_instance
teststack.DatabaseServer.MySqlDatabaseServer
teststack.WikiServerOne

Fixes Issue #160
Fixes Issue #136

Thanks to asalkeld@redhat.com for helping sort out the unit
test cases.

Change-Id: I14f4551feb41c7f98caa30dd98f997da6d00c467
Signed-off-by: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add a version to pytz.

Upcoming improvements to pip 1.4 (wheel support and
skip-pre-release-by-default) mean that pytz without a version
will be skipped. Adding a version here gets us what we want.

Adding an intial lower-bound on the version that's currently in RHEL6,
since we don't actually care about the version itself.

pytz uses date based versioning which isn't supported by default:

http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#date-based-versions

Change-Id: Ieb0cda61b2f8665d5f83ff8beb8a4cf5b4ece011

'}, {'account_id': 7629, 'date': '2013-07-11 14:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(12 inline comments)

Sadly, this is not a trivial refactor. The reason these deprecated methods have hung around so long is that you often have to seriously refactor code to get to where you *can* meaningfully use the new methods. The new SOAP methods allow a client using vCenter or ESXi (collectively known as vSphere) to scale out. Clients that use the old methods get whole resultsets as a single chunk and can get bogged, lagged, or otherwise have problems.

Also, it looks like you will have to add at least two new methods to vim_util.py one for cancel RetrieveResult and one for continue RetrieveResult since you may have multiple pages of results on any given traversal or query.

Three salient points...

1. RetrieveResult is returned by http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-51/index.jsp#com.vmware.wssdk.apiref.doc/vmodl.query.PropertyCollector.html#retrievePropertiesEx so you can read up on the actual data structures there, the code you have in fake.py is right shape-wise but wrong name-wise and that could confuse people in the future.

2. when you don't care about the "extra" results you call http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-51/index.jsp#com.vmware.wssdk.apiref.doc/vmodl.query.PropertyCollector.html#cancelRetrievePropertiesEx "cancel" to tell the server it can free the return results (it lets the vSphere host free up memory)

3. when you want the other results you call ContinueRetrievePropertiesEx   http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-51/index.jsp#com.vmware.wssdk.apiref.doc/vmodl.query.PropertyCollector.html#continueRetrievePropertiesEx'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-07-11 19:19:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Use RetrievePropertiesEx instead of RetrieveProperties

Fixes bug 1183654

The fix also adds a configuration variable enabling the user to
configure the maximum amount of objects that can be retrieved by
the aforementioned function.

When using RetrievePropertiesEx the server may allocate resources
in case additional calls are made. These are addressed by reading the
extra resources using ContinueRetrievePropertiesEx (if necessary)
or CancelRetrievePropertiesEx (when the necessary result has been found).

DocImpact

Change-Id: I894d9698461b0ce22b01211fd196f6c32899a8fd

commit_message:
Update references with new Mailing List location

Yesterday, openstack@lists.launchpad.org was migrated with
all users to openstack@list.openstack.org.

This patch updates references to the old mailing list with the
new, to ensure that people encountering them don't accidentally
try and join the old list!

Change-Id: I76242f4f4f0c8c2418068ea709ab2f7aa4502fd5

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-25 13:52:52.000000000', 'message': 'Set VM instance to right state if code migration failed

If a SHUTOFF VM migrate failed because of no valid host, then
the VM will be set to ACTIVE but actually the VM is SHUTOFF.

The fix was that set VM to original state if got no valid host
exception.

Fix bug 1204905

commit_message:
Set VM back to its original state if cold migration failed

If migration of a VM in the SHUTOFF state failed due to
NoValidHost, the VM was erroneously set to ACTIVE.

The fix sets the VM back to its original state instead.

Fix bug 1204905

Change-Id: I06f6a2e8a05e715c505a24d3013f482eaea3df8b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-25 12:45:20.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore non-existing attr in APIResourceWrapper __repr__

Fixes bug 1202415

__repr__ was added to APIResourceWrapper in the recent commit,
but it searches all attributes in _attrs list. When an attribute
defined in _attrs actually does not exist, __repr__() fails.
This commit changes __repr__ to ignore non-existing attributes.

Change-Id: Iebaeae78f3763d87f3993ba5c4bbed4c23e84c45
'}]
commit_message:
Ignore non-existing attr in APIResourceWrapper __repr__

Fixes bug 1202415

__repr__ was added to APIResourceWrapper in the recent commit,
but it searches all attributes in _attrs list. When an attribute
defined in _attrs actually does not exist, __repr__() fails.
This commit changes __repr__ to ignore non-existing attributes.

Change-Id: Iebaeae78f3763d87f3993ba5c4bbed4c23e84c45

commit_message:
Fix stubs setup and exception message formatting

Fixes time-dependent bug in test case stubs setup that could result
in stubs being unset by GC.

bug 1205091

Change-Id: Ic0d97bd1f96e42631c1ba3e1eaf4cf74b36140b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-29 15:43:14.000000000', 'message': 'Update to latest oslo rootwrap

Update Neutron rootwrap to the latest from oslo-incubator. This allows
to get rid of the DnsMasqFilter (which was already replaced by
EnvFilter) in preparation for the havana release, as well as get a few
bugfixes.

All the changes are coming directly from the Oslo "rootwrap" module
sync.

Change-Id: Ic373710cce0716323f4349414bb5b231f48d9177
'}]
commit_message:
Update to latest oslo rootwrap

Update Neutron rootwrap to the latest from oslo-incubator. This allows
to get rid of the DnsMasqFilter (which was already replaced by
EnvFilter) in preparation for the havana release, as well as get a few
bugfixes.

All the changes are coming directly from the Oslo "rootwrap" module
sync.

Change-Id: Ic373710cce0716323f4349414bb5b231f48d9177

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-19 04:47:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add boto tests for idempotent RunInstances calls

The EC2 API supports providing a unique client token to
the RunInstances call to ensure idempotency. In other words,
multiple RunInstances call with the same client token will
not start up multiple instances.

This adds a test for this condition, including ensuring that
a new instance is spawned when a client token is re-used
after the original instance linked to it has been terminated.

Fixes bug #1202404

Change-Id: Ia11eb9ac082a623a1ad03b89fb6dbf7cad9f9c99
'}]
commit_message:
Add boto tests for idempotent RunInstances calls

The EC2 API supports providing a unique client token to
the RunInstances call to ensure idempotency. In other words,
multiple RunInstances call with the same client token will
not start up multiple instances.

This adds a test for this condition, including ensuring that
a new instance is spawned when a client token is re-used
after the original instance linked to it has been terminated.

Fixes bug #1202404

Change-Id: Ia11eb9ac082a623a1ad03b89fb6dbf7cad9f9c99

commit_message:
Fix policy default_rule issue

This patch fixed the following issue in policy:

    1. Default_rule wasn't set correctly when using enforcer.
    2. When overwrite=True set_rule method doesn't work.
    3. Add type check in __missing__ of dict and return
       the correct value of default_rule.
    4. Partially refactor the test_policy code based on the
       related change.

Fixed #bug 1202771

Change-Id: I9be1ac8bdc995adae201e9b45ee124dd525e4822

commit_message:
Rackspace database resource output is null

current implementation of rackspace database resource
_resolve_attribute method assumes that clouddatabase object's
hostname and href are set to correct values and just returns
them, but that assumption is not correct. With this change,
hostname/href is retrived if it was not set already.

Fixes Bug #1204601

Change-Id: Ifca44237e20210b5ff1fc1b28f1f8408f5672ae4

commit_message:
XenAPI: Refactor Fake to create pools, SRs and VIFs automatically

Required for changing the default SR to be the pool default - see
I116f65ece94f839e63b085480ba4f8974119d2bb
This also fixes some minor bugs in fake.py shown up by the tests

Change-Id: I19fc0747648b97a0912d28008981a84f70107d7b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-23 01:51:07.000000000', 'message': 'Implements new metadata endpoint

This patchset removes the ability to specify metadata when creating a
queue as per the Marconi Weekly Meeting held on July 18th, 2013.

It also adds a new endpoint: /v1/queues/{name}/metadata with operations
- GET
- PUT

New unit tests added to capture expected behavior. Old tests also
updated to reflect new endpoint and behavior.

Change-Id: Ie3a79a63a865035a789609dac770adabe4dc6ed7
Implements: blueprint metadata-resource
'}, {'created': '2013-07-24 21:29:53.000000000', 'message': 'Implements new metadata endpoint

- GET
- PUT

- GET /v1/queues/{queue_name}  # replaced by metadata ^^

updated to reflect new endpoint and behavior.

Change-Id: Ie3a79a63a865035a789609dac770adabe4dc6ed7
Implements: blueprint metadata-resource
'}, {'created': '2013-07-25 14:52:12.000000000', 'message': 'Implements new metadata endpoint

This patchset removes the ability to specify metadata when creating a
queue as per the Marconi Weekly Meeting held on July 18th, 2013.

It also adds a new endpoint: /v1/queues/{name}/metadata with operations
- GET
- PUT

Removes:
- GET /v1/queues/{queue_name}  # replaced by metadata ^^
- the request body from PUT /v1/queues/{queue_name}

Rationale:

The addition of the metadata endpoint increases the extensibility of
the API, and decouples metadata updates from queue creation. This
makes it easier for us in the future to add other endpoints, say
/v1/queues/{name}/config for modifying special values that change the
behavior of the queue.

With that addition, creating a queue with metadata became slightly
more dangerous. In the case where a user accidentally tries to create
a queue that already exists, the metadata for the existing queue would
be overwritten by the PUT request body. By removing the ability to
modify metadata at queue creation time, it also prevents these types
of accidents.

Tests:

New unit tests added to capture expected behavior. Old tests were also
updated to reflect new endpoint and behavior.

Change-Id: Ie3a79a63a865035a789609dac770adabe4dc6ed7
Implements: blueprint metadata-resource

commit_message:
Implements new metadata endpoint

This patchset removes the ability to specify metadata when creating a
queue as per the Marconi Weekly Meeting held on July 18th, 2013.

It also adds a new endpoint: /v1/queues/{name}/metadata with operations
- GET
- PUT

Removes:
- GET /v1/queues/{queue_name}  # replaced by metadata ^^
- the request body from PUT /v1/queues/{queue_name}

Rationale:

The addition of the metadata endpoint increases the extensibility of
the API, and decouples metadata updates from queue creation. This
makes it easier for us in the future to add other endpoints, say
/v1/queues/{name}/config for modifying special values that change the
behavior of the queue.

With that addition, creating a queue with metadata became slightly
more dangerous. In the case where a user accidentally tries to create
a queue that already exists, the metadata for the existing queue would
be overwritten by the PUT request body. By removing the ability to
modify metadata at queue creation time, it also prevents these types
of accidents.

Tests:

New unit tests added to capture expected behavior. Old tests were also
updated to reflect new endpoint and behavior.

Storage API changes:
- storage(queue): get -> get_metadata

Change-Id: Ie3a79a63a865035a789609dac770adabe4dc6ed7
Implements: blueprint metadata-resource

commit_message:
Add wait_for_volume_status in upload_to_image test

The upload to image test was relying on the status of the
image being uploaded to indicate whether things were completed
or not before exiting.  It appears that in some cases there
is a timing condition here where the volume's status may not
have been updated from in-use back to available before the image
is ready, resulting in tearDown being called and attempting to
delete an in-use volume which raises an unhandled exception in
the tearDown.

Fixes bug: 1202254

Change-Id: If39caa3fdd301ba4b35670b103251e89f20b3edb

commit_message:
Fixes Hbase metadata query return wrong result

Based on current implement of Hbase metadata query  in Ceilometer,
it's trying to compare the metadata value with the metadata stored
in table "resource" instead of table "meter", when user query a
specific meter name. As a result, the query result will be wrong.
See:
https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/master/ceilometer/storage/impl_hbase.py#L441
https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/master/ceilometer/storage/impl_mongodb.py#L535

Fixes bug 1205759

Change-Id: I3f8168fa5371985ac135b0a9d41e76d7bc71c4a7

commit_message:
remove 'import *' usage (or mark is #noqa)

This is talked in bug #1188533, and in current codes, there are several
places here:

horizon/forms/__init__.py:18:from django.forms import *
    mark '# noqa'

openstack_dashboard/settings.py:182:    from local.local_settings import *
openstack_dashboard/test/settings.py:5:from horizon.test.settings import *
    mark '# noqa'

openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/workflows/__init__.py:1:from create_instance import *
openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/workflows/__init__.py:2:from update_instance import *
openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/workflows/__init__.py:3:from resize_instance import *
    fix it

openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/images_and_snapshots/urls.py:21:from django.conf.urls.defaults import *
    fix it

fixes bug # 1188533
Change-Id: Id671280903f8452a78f81f1240d92297de7a89a8

commit_message:
Use valid IP addresses values in tests

Currently we use strings like 'fake_address', 'localhost', etc
as IP addresses values in DP API tests. This works great when
running tests on SQLite or MySQL backends, where IP addresses
are stored as plain strings. But in PostgreSQL there is a special
column type (INET), which checks inserted values to be valid IP
addresses, so tests fail.

This patch ensures we use valid IP addresses values instead of
arbitrary strings in DB API tests.

Blueprint: db-api-tests-on-all-backends

Change-Id: I2026bab612fcac09b245f6745810b6200f1f2443

commit_message:
Integrate Oozie deployment for Vanilla Plugin

* Supports Oozie 3.3.2 version
* Able to install multiple Oozie instances
* Configures core-site.xml for hadoop user and oozie hostanmes
* Updates cluster info with Oozie URLs
* Fixes broken unit-tests

NOTE: Oozie integration requiers special image built by DIB.
      See edp-dib-element-oozie-vanilla

blueprint edp-oozie-for-vanilla-plugin

Change-Id: I86fbd599baae06dc20d3f444dcb01b7cf044077e

[{'created': '2013-07-18 14:26:47.000000000', 'message': "Change EC2 client tokens to use system_metadata

An EC2 client token is created as a result of RunInstances. The initial
implementation called create_tags which uses per-instance metadata.
However, we can't update per-instance metadata while an instance is still
building because put the metadata updates in the messaging queue.

We avoid this problem by using system_metadata instead of per-instance
metadata. As an added bonus, users can't tamper with the token via the tags
API.

Fixes bug #1202404

Change-Id: I8ff28d75154a30fe3b521926453b9e9cbdd9fead
"}, {'created': '2013-07-18 18:29:29.000000000', 'message': "Change EC2 client tokens to use system_metadata

An EC2 client token is created as a result of RunInstances. The initial
implementation called create_tags which uses per-instance metadata.
However, we can't update per-instance metadata while an instance is still
building because put the metadata updates in the messaging queue.

We avoid this problem by using system_metadata instead of per-instance
metadata. As an added bonus, users can't tamper with the token via the tags
API.

Fixes bug #1202404

Change-Id: I8ff28d75154a30fe3b521926453b9e9cbdd9fead
"}]
commit_message:
Change EC2 client tokens to use system_metadata

An EC2 client token is created as a result of RunInstances. The initial
implementation called create_tags which uses per-instance metadata.
However, we can't update per-instance metadata while an instance is still
building because put the metadata updates in the messaging queue.

We avoid this problem by using system_metadata instead of per-instance
metadata. As an added bonus, users can't tamper with the token via the tags
API.

Fixes bug #1202404

Change-Id: I8ff28d75154a30fe3b521926453b9e9cbdd9fead

commit_message:
Make Ubuntu 13.04 (raring) the default release

Ubuntu 13.04 has been released now for 3 months. The updated libvirt,
openvswitch and kernel are all beneficial to various OpenStack components,
and many other software is updated beyond the versions in Ubuntu 12.10.

Change-Id: I358aed8bf906c3ff5103f19b1f9e6ac689b5d5ee

commit_message:
Shows a warning message when deleting a container that contains data.

We cannot delete objects in the container since there may be millions
of objects in that. The batch deletion should be done in swift instead
of Horizon. The batch remove of objects function is only in swift CLI
command now. This commit replace the unclear message with a warning
message that tells the user the container is not empy.

Related bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1034890

Fixes bug: #1096084

Change-Id: I59b46a3535b8654734c3dae4eec916ab1b53c716
(cherry picked from commit eae19c1a7c2303e398b3348651482f49ea7508ce)

commit_message:
Allow connect by FC-only or iSCSI-only systems.

Currently the brick code raises exceptions if it cannot determine the
initiator name or FC HBA information. This patch makes this information
optional, as Nova does.

Fixes: bug 1203486

Change-Id: I8efc101d7ac980261a8bc5d74209cafe4b06cc15

commit_message:
Fix dnsmasq package install failure

1. added gettext to quantum_dhcp_build_packages, or it throws 'ERROR xgettext: Command not found'
2. made dnsmasq_all to be installed last to fix install failure due to version dependency on dnsmasq-base(>= 2.65-1)
3. fixed typo in l3_agent.ini.erb, or quantum-l3-agent fails to launch

Change-Id: If3e263dc7dc39328b68458cc145bdfff8ffcc81a

commit_message:
Fine-grained policy control about security-group.

Now the policies about security-group are too simple,
which can't enforce actions like 'index/update/delete/create'.

The patch add policy rules about security-groups.
The new polices include:
* index/update/delete/create/show security-groups.
* create/delete security-group rules.

Since create/update/delete/create security groups and rules are
in Neutron, do not port these to nova V3 API.

Implemented bp: enforce-security-policy
Change-Id: I632fe9d1a89de6fd4c168019d510ef197a278d54

subject: kernel vxlan TypeDriver (WIP)
messages:
[{'account_id': 7170, 'date': '2013-07-29 09:30:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-07-29 09:30:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-07-29 13:46:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

We don't want to differentiate between VXLAN with and without multicast by using a separate TypeDriver in ML2. The existing VXLAN TypeDriver should be able to support both at the same time. The fact we chose to set the multicast group as a configuration option initially was for simplicity. Thus, I think we should just modify the existing VXLAN TypeDriver to support multicast mode similar to the way this is done here.

Also, one other thing to keep in mind is that VXLAN+multicast requires you to configure multicast in your network. Having Neutron manage the endpoints itself makes this easier for some people to use VXLAN, IMHO."}, {'account_id': 7170, 'date': '2013-07-30 08:34:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

I'll try to modify the existing vxlan type driver, add a extra parameter to guide the agent which implementation to use."}]

kernel vxlan TypeDriver (WIP)

Implements: blueprint openvswitch-kernel-vxlan

commit_message:
Fix running of migrations tests by Jenkins gate

DB schema migrations tests are always skipped for MySQL
and PostgreSQL backends, when running gate jobs. This is
due to the bug in the function, which checks, if given DB
backend is available.

Fixes bug 1205386

Change-Id: I80d5da64347279b8fb5a975ff0d11f31fe35c6ce

commit_message:
Make row actions menu visible for the lower row

In every tab on any page with a few tabs (like Load Balancers
or Access & Security pages) there is a bottom border. If any
row actions menu is too long, its bottom is hidden for the lower
row. This patch removes the line which actually prevents menu
from running below border.

fixes bug 1190548

Change-Id: I244c7ee383bebaa85e1f4db08972af37160e2185

I think it's a good idea to get rid of the global monkeypatching, but I'm curious about what effects removing that extra logic about _LOCALEDIR will have."}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-06-14 21:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think that almost all modules uses this function. So I am not sure that such changes are good.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2013-06-14 22:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-14 22:23:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/33112/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/2129 : SUCCESS in 2m 09s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/33112/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/1904/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 26s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33112/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/1753 : SUCCESS in 2m 20s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33112/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/2088 : SUCCESS in 3m 40s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33112/1/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/2089 : SUCCESS in 3m 00s
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-17 06:22:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

No point even considering this without a migration plan away from gettext.install()

e.g. at least a patch for Nova please?

Even a more considered explanation why you think we should stop doing this would be helpful

We've been doing gettext.install() for a long time but see e.g. If4125d6bcbde63df95de129ac5c83b4a6d6f130a for some thoughts on when it's reasonable to use:

gettext.install() sets up a default translation domain from the process. If a module may be used in a process whose default translation domain may not be the translation domain associated with the module, then that module should not use the _() builtin.

e.g. if nova.exception should ever be imported by something like ceilometer, then nova.exception should have a _() function which looks up translations in the 'nova' translation domain not the 'nova' translation domain.

Yes, we could take this approach everywhere and remove the gettext.install() code. I'd be fine with that if someone was willing to go to the trouble of making it happen. I don't exactly know what it fixes, though. And it doesn't make sense to remove gettextutils.install() from oslo-incubator until all the projects are moved off it."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Removed unnecesary monkey patching of the builtins

Users who need the _ function should simply import
it on an as needed basis.

Change-Id: I6570f16a3200839be821cbe8c818849ccb4a2225

'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-06-11 14:45:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Last time this change was proposed, there were concerns about changing the default in a backwards-incompatible way for no strong reason.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29095/

Perhaps in this case it would be better to update the documentation instead?

(Also, for future reference, we usually try to have a bug # associated with a review.)'}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2013-06-11 14:57:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I wasn't aware of the previous patch when I submitted this :/

I would think using internalURL is better than changing the doc, if only because I would expect internalURLs to be using a more secure network, and this would avoid sending traffic on the public network where people might try to do bad things."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-06-17 20:22:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

As Julie noted, a doc fix would be much better instead of changing the code. There's no community consensus around a sane default for this value, and any change would be a massive backwards incompatiblity that would have to be documented and would force people to update their config files for existing deployments.

Please update the docs to match the code."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2013-06-17 20:40:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Gabriel: before I go and change the doc (and the default used for the keystone client!): what's your take on my concern about the fact that not using internalURL is less secure?

I'm slightly worried that not doing this change now is just leaving the door open to have this change done later on when we will realize that it really should have been secured by default. And we will suffer from the backwards incompatibility issue even more in that case.

But if you're confident this will not be an issue in the future, then okay."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Always use internalURL as default for OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE

The documentation explicitly says internalURL is the default, but
publicURL was used (except for keystone, which has the correct default).

Change-Id: I1fbcdda21a32b2b56b8a57749c7061bf0601e02e

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

If the race issue can be solved just by adapting the model as Maru suggests (and I tend to agree with his suggestion), the problem should be sorted in this way.

It seems a similar approach can be adopted for bug 1994206, making the cidr unique.

VMs being allocated the same IP in theory might be solved also with this approach, even if the solution will probably not be what one expects (the allocation will fail even if more IPs are available).

I would therefore join Maru in his invite to shelve this patch and resume the blueprint when we'll really see the need for distribution locks."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

This patch displays a lack of understanding of how to maintain db consistency - please abandon.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please explain why the proposed solution is preferable to using a unique index on the mac address column."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not merge

I'm not a fan of this approach either.  

Adding a unique constraint as Maru suggested will ensure data integrity.  We also need to think about the response a client will receive to a perfectly valid request.  A db constraint error should be expected in code like this and I think we should have to code to intelligently retry before returning an error to the client.  My intent is to address this case as part of the IPAM refactoring."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-06-21 14:52:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

The bug mentions calling cleanup_nova() from unstack.sh but that is not what you've done.  unstack.sh can make no assumptions about the running services or lack thereof so calling any APIs from there is not going to work."}, {'account_id': 6685, 'date': '2013-06-21 15:31:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks Dean for your comments. First of all, I think that I didn't do a good job in coming up with the bug title and its description. So I went ahead and reworded them. Please check it out and let me know if they make sense.

Secondly, unstack.sh imports stackrc which in turn imports localrc. So If I hadn't misunderstood your comments, what services are running on a particular node are actually known in unstack.sh.  

On the other hand, the existing cleanup_nova() is problematic in this regard as well. For example, a user could have removed n-cpu from localrc. Thus, during stack.sh, nova instances created in the last run would still remain. 

I tested the change and it's working as far as I can see."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-06-24 21:19:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

My comment about running services was actually that nova's API and any other nova services can not be assumed to still be running.

You are right that changing the ENABLED_SERVICES in localrc before running unstack.sh can be problematic, but that's true for every service not just Nova.  Still it might make sense to move the n-cpu enabled check out of cleanup_nova()."}, {'account_id': 6685, 'date': '2013-06-26 12:39:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Dean,

If you look at unstack.sh, is_service_enabled call is made in many places in a small script. 

I understand your concern that nova service might not be there when unstack.sh is invoked. For example, the user could manually shut it down or it might have just crashed, etc.. However, in a normal circumstances, the change does work at least in the following scenario:
      1. invoke stack.sh 
      2. create some instances
      3. invoke unstack.sh

The above will work in both single-node or multi-node devstack, and it will address the concern described in the bug. 

Please do let me know what your recommendations are to proceed on this.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Nova instances were left intact after unstack.sh. This change is to delete them
after unstack.sh. A user can still choose not to by setting
UNSTACK_CLEANUP_NOVA=no in localrc

Fix Bug 1168395

Change-Id: I4df51fec1355cb9cb4818babccc3fe5cfdc71070

On Fedora, both the chroot image and the image file are written
to a tmpfs that is limited by size to half of physical memory.
On a system with 8GB of memory, a 4GB tmpfs is not enough space
to produce an image. The compressed image file is now written to
tmp.

Change-Id: Ib621dfffa37bd5152c24938819560230b06e69f5
'}, {'created': '2013-07-30 06:03:17.000000000', 'message': 'Write image to a different location

On Fedora, both the chroot image and the image file are written
to a tmpfs that is limited by size to half of physical memory.
On a system with 8GB of memory, a 4GB tmpfs is not enough space
to produce an image. The image file is now written to cwd which
is likely to have more space.

Change-Id: Ib621dfffa37bd5152c24938819560230b06e69f5
'}]
commit_message:
Write image to a different location

On Fedora, both the chroot image and the image file are written
to a tmpfs that is limited by size to half of physical memory.
On a system with 8GB of memory, a 4GB tmpfs is not enough space
to produce an image. The compressed image file is now written to
tmp.

Change-Id: Ib621dfffa37bd5152c24938819560230b06e69f5

commit_message:
serialize the subnet creation function

Bug #1194206

self._validate_subnet_cidr(context, network, s['cidr']) depends
on existing db records. In current env, it will allow duplicate CIDR
to be inserted into DB at the same time.

This fix can avoid this case.

Change-Id: Ic6bc88d7eaa2b5ae6464b37d6ae0ac10a620fb0a

commit_message:
Added support for testing with Vagrant.

Vagrantfile and supporting files for the successful installation
of the chef server and uploading of recipes using spiceweasel/berkshelf.

README.md updated with howto use instructions.  Tested with just the
os-base role, but plan is to have a vm definition for the allinone
role when all the cookbooks are ready.

Change-Id: I9b93c4054677013966aececa3093711d0c91bcbd

btw, I guess it's better to use flatten rather than flat?"}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2013-06-26 18:31:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-06-27 04:18:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Do not merge

If I understand correctly, this API only makes sense for certain back-ends, and makes things a lot less 'transparent'.  Now the user is troubled with implementation details.  Why is this API necessary?  If you would like to support deleting a volume that has snapshots, couldn't that be done entirely in the driver?  In other words, if the Ceph/Nexenta driver gets a delete_volume call, and it sees that there are dependencies, it could flatten those out before deleting.  What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 1107, 'date': '2013-06-27 04:49:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

This isn't pushing something new onto users, it's making an implicit requirement explicit.

It's also not about deleting volumes with snapshots. The dependency described in the blueprint is that of a clone on its parent snapshot. Automatically flattening when you delete the parent volume is undesirable because it will produce a lot of I/O and increased space usage at once, since there may be many clones to flatten."}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-06-27 05:22:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (5 inline comments)

Well, yes, put it into the driver may be a good idea for transparent, but if do so ,the delete_volume is likely to be a Deny of Service point to the backend.

Imaging a user create a base volume ,and create a lot of dependency through snap/create_from_volume, then when user delete the volume ,the backend driver need to do a lot of "flatten" , which is likely to result the backend run out of space(because of thin provision) or overload.Also, it will block volume backend driver thread for very long time. This kind of usage may be a attack from hacker, or just a use case for special internal user.

A separate flatten call gives user more flexible,user can flat the volume one by one.
Another scenario is for the backends implemented their clone or snap via CoW, user can use this API to flat the volume, thus can get better random write(modification) performance'}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-06-27 06:27:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6939, 'date': '2013-06-27 06:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-27 07:13:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/33579/7/check/gate-cinder-pep8/4499 : SUCCESS in 3m 22s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/33579/7/check/gate-cinder-docs/4393/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 5m 20s

- http://logs.openstack.org/33579/7/check/gate-cinder-pylint/716 : SUCCESS in 4m 40s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/33579/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/26686 : SUCCESS in 45m 03s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33579/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/26392 : SUCCESS in 43m 34s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33579/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/34355 : SUCCESS in 20m 37s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33579/7/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/13212 : FAILURE in 20m 54s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-06-27 07:52:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Nothing really special about this -1 since I haven't reviewed the new patchset yet.

I kind of agree Avishay's point on not to expose implementation details to end-user *IF* this explicit dependency only happens to a few back-end, which means other back-end either don't have dependency or they deal with it by their own already.

And Josh, to my understanding, flattening causes problems on back-ends no matter it's auto or manual in the case you mentioned (one parent and 1,000 cloned child). In my previous discussion with Xiaoxi, I don't making this call explicit can do any significantly good to 'protect' back-end.  Think of the case when 100 users come and try to flatten volume manually at the same time.  What's the difference when 100 users try to delete parent volume and then cause back-end to do auto flattening?

I don't think Xiaoxi's reasoning about making API user-visible are valid. 1. It's _NOT_ end user's responsibility to prevent back-end from overload.  Totally NOT! 2. It's even worse to advise this feature as a 'performance tuning trick' to end user.

I think it is worth a discussion involving boarder audiences to see if such dependency is common and then decide if we want this bp to be implemented."}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-06-27 07:54:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

Please revise commit message.'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-06-27 08:25:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Please add to agenda for next week's meeting"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-07-03 18:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Do not merge

I talked about this with Josh and we agree to abandon this change and moving to implement automatically flatten and rate-limit control inside cinder.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Implementation for bp add-flat-volume-api

implemented blueprint add-flat-volume-api

For some backends such like ceph ,nexenta LVM V2 ,they use CoW/Layering
mechanism for cloning, that introduce a dependency between child volume
and its parent.We need a way to remove such dependency but not deleted
the child volume

I prefer to remain such api user-visible because
    1.it provide more flexibility for user to prevent backend from overload
    2.user may want to flat a volume just want a better write performance
      compared to CoW

Yes it lose some transparent but if user try to flat
    a) a volume from a backend that naturaly flatten
    b) a volume without any dependency
nothing happened and no any side-effect.
Another BP that aimed at implementing flat_volume for
Ceph/RBD driver is ongoing but depends on this patch

Change-Id: Ic6c1fe19cd2ee777548a4e67fd75f0438f2760da

[{'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'message': 'Network namespace wrapper for VPNaaS reference driver

Provides the wrapper required for Blueprint ipsec-vpn-reference

Strongswan that will be used for this first implementation can't
be launched several times in the same host "as is", because its
configuration, pid and control socket files location are hard coded.

As Strongswan will be launched in a network namespace using "ip netns"
command, it will also run in a mount namespace created by this command.

The solution consists in using a wrapper that bind-mount the required
directories in a speratate folder, this mount will only affect the subprocess
launched by the wrapper.

Change-Id: I6e82e6b7ac9882b14a060e336d6b6199b74c13c8
'}, {'created': '2013-07-06 16:06:39.000000000', 'message': 'Network namespace wrapper for VPNaaS reference driver

command, it will also run in a mount namespace created by this command.

The solution consists in using a wrapper that bind-mount the required
directories in a speratate folder, this mount will only affect the subprocess
launched by the wrapper.

This wrapper also enforces rootwrap filter validation to make sure it can't
be used to run unauthorized commands as root

The wrapper can be launched as follow:

ip netns exec test_ns quantum-netns-wrapper -d \
--cmd "ipsec, start" \
--mount_paths /etc,/var/run \
--mount_prefix /opt/stack/data/quantum/ipsec/ \

commit_message:
Network namespace wrapper for VPNaaS reference driver

Provides the wrapper required for Blueprint ipsec-vpn-reference

Strongswan that will be used for this first implementation can't
be launched several times in the same host "as is", because its
configuration, pid and control socket files location are hard coded.

As Strongswan will be launched in a network namespace using "ip netns"
command, it will also run in a mount namespace created by this command.

The solution consists in using a wrapper that bind-mount the required
directories in a speratate folder, this mount will only affect the subprocess
launched by the wrapper.

This wrapper also enforces rootwrap filter validation to make sure it can't
be used to run unauthorized commands as root

The wrapper can be launched as follow:
sudo /usr/local/bin/quantum-rootwrap /etc/quantum/rootwrap.conf \
ip netns exec test_ns quantum-netns-wrapper -d \
--cmd "ipsec, start" \
--mount_paths /etc,/var/run \
--mount_prefix /opt/stack/data/quantum/ipsec/ \
--rootwrap_config /etc/quantum/rootwrap.conf

Change-Id: I6e82e6b7ac9882b14a060e336d6b6199b74c13c8

commit_message:
Changed assertEquals to assertEqual() in tests

Based on the review comment in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29396/6
indicating that assertEquals() is deprecated in preference to
assertEqual(), all the tests that use assertEquals are replaced
with assertEqual.

Change-Id: Iff1c45672fc0f3af1e8e50635886cb9fb2ad9efc

(1 inline comment)

I'm really not sure about this ... it works only for a subset of cinder use cases.  It's fine for the default LVM based volume driver, but it doesn't make sense for any other driver.  That's the only time that 'host' is actually where the volume lives.

It needs to at least be very clear in the documentation that this limitation exists.  So, please add it to the commit message.

I also wonder if it's worth changing the name of the filter to make it clear it only works for the LVM driver?"}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-06-21 08:10:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

This is something we were also thinking on. THe only thing that I do not like is that the filter will fail if it is not able to select the very same host where the volume is stored. Do you think it is worth to introduce a "soft" hint, where it would try to schedule the vm to the same host, but if it is not avaialble it will continue and not fail?'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-06-21 09:59:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-06-21 10:30:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

to Russell: Agreed. I have expanded the commit message and the docstring. As for the name of the filter I don't think we should change it. At least here https://review.openstack.org/27051 it can be used as well.

to Alvaro: Yes, I was thinking about such possibility, but eventually decided against it as I was afraid that it would overcomplicate the filter (I mean from the perspective of a user) and make it do what it was not intended to do. Now the filter fails when it can't find a volume as this seems to be a serious issue for a user who wants to connect it to a new instance. If it is not such a big deal I think that maybe it is better not to use a filter and to use specific weighter function which works in similar way instead and rely on it in cases when it is not crucial to have a volume attached."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-06-21 10:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Yup, using a weighter seems much better in this case.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-21 10:41:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 6828, 'date': '2013-06-27 15:12:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

First of all, thanks a lot for your work.
However, I wondering if this filter should work with cinder multi-backend enabled?
If cinder multi-backend is enabled, "os-vol-host-attr:host" does not return the name of the host, but something like: hostname@backend_name.

Maybe you can correct your patch to work with multi-backend enabled, or add a comment to specify that multi-backend is not supported?

Thanks a lot!
Regards'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-07-01 10:17:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-07-01 10:45:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

It seems the suggestion about using a weighting function instead of a filter was lost.  Thoughts on that?'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-07-02 09:19:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

to Russell: I was thinking about a separate patch for introducing this weighter function. If it is needed here I'll upload it in the next patchset."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-07-02 12:50:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

I was actually thinking that a weight may make more sense than a filter.  It's always a good idea to try to localize instances to their volumes.  The user shouldn't have to pass a special hint to get that behavior.  If this were changed to be a weight function and used the information in the instance's block device mappings, that's what we would get.  I still would not have this on by default though, since it only works for some (one?) volume driver."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-02 12:57:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

to Russel: If the weighter is correctly coded it should be safely enabled by default: in the case that the driver is not compatible, 0 should be the weight.'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-07-02 13:44:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

to Russell: yes, a default weighter seems like a good idea, but I still think that a filter is usefull too as a user might want to force an instance on specific host. I've registered a blueprint for this one: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/volume-affinity-weighter-function

I think that the filter and the weighter function can coexist peacefully, as they actually do a little different jobs."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-07-03 02:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

The filter is more difficult to use, as it requires a scheduler hint, instead of "just working".  The only thing it provides over the weight function is making it so the instance won't even boot if it can not be located with the instance.  I don't get why you would ever want that behavior.

I guess it's time we take it to the mailing list since gerrit isn't a great place for discussion.'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-07-04 13:05:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

to all: by the way, how exactly the weighter function can be enabled by default and implicitly? AFAIK we'll still need a hint to be passed to weighter function. Or am I missing anything?"}, {'account_id': 6828, 'date': '2013-07-05 08:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: No score

Hi Alexey, in the context of "boot from volume" is it possible to retrieve the hint automatically?'}, {'account_id': 6938, 'date': '2013-07-05 10:58:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

to jerome: as far as I can tell in the case of booting from volume volume_id is placed in another dictionary which never gets to scheduler.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2013-07-05 11:08:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Alexey: "by the way, how exactly the weighter function can be enabled by default and implicitly? AFAIK we'll still need a hint to be passed to weighter function. Or am I missing anything?"

No, you don't need any hint. The weigher should get the host where the volume is stored, and give a weight to it (lets say 1), and no weight (0) if it is not there. If the volume is not in any host (i.e. it is an external service) it should give a 0 weigth to all of them. If there driver is not appropriate, a 0 weight should be returned for all of them.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Implementation of Volume Affinity Filter.

This filter allows one to schedule an instance on the same host
to which specific volume belongs. Please note that this works
only if the driver used by cinder has a notion of host (for
example the LVM driver).  It also must be noted that currently
the filter does not support multi-backend, however this may change
in future.

Blueprint volume-affinity-filter

DocImpact

Change-Id: If86acacafb1ba363c31d067fab902d594371dde6

commit_message:
Fix bad request response code on extra_specs create.

This commit changes the error response on a bad body from 422 to 400 for
an extra spec create request.

Fixes bug 1090356

Change-Id: I7925bbd53fb9647440532b206feee3421fb9f38b
(cherry picked from commit 6a7e93dfc750e08e95c6b53b122407c763883c6c)

subject: Add a "not_empty" flag for string options
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1994, 'name': 'Zhongyue Luo', 'email': 'zhongyue.luo@gmail.com', 'username': 'zyluo'}, {'_account_id': 6473, 'name': 'Sunil Thaha', 'email': 'sthaha@redhat.com', 'username': 'sthaha'}, {'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 7231, 'name': 'Jason Dillaman', 'username': 'jdillaman', 'inactive': True}]

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-12 06:17:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36783/1/check/gate-oslo.config-pep8/212 : SUCCESS in 34s

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-07-12 06:42:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

one question inline"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-12 07:26:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I'm really not keen on adding a flag for every possible validation check we may want to do - e.g. alphanumeric_separated_only_by_periods

Why can't the code which uses this value check its validity before using it?"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-07-12 10:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

> I'm really not keen on adding a flag for every possible validation check we may want to do - e.g. alphanumeric_separated_only_by_periods

Well, I'm not proposing alphanumeric_separated_only_by_periods :)  

My feeling was that there are many options where it would make sense to say "you must specify something here" as a sanity check.

If you want alphanumeric_* then there may be an argument for passing a regex with options; oslo.config might be a nice common place to implement that and as a result provide more consistent error reporting across projects.  I don't have a feeling for how useful that would be, however.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-07-12 10:22:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-12 10:23:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36783/2/check/gate-oslo.config-pep8/213 : SUCCESS in 44s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/36783/2/check/gate-oslo.config-docs/213/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 43s
- http://logs.openstack.org/36783/2/check/gate-oslo.config-python26/214 : SUCCESS in 58s
- http://logs.openstack.org/36783/2/check/gate-oslo.config-python27/213 : SUCCESS in 41s
'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-07-12 10:37:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Why can't the code which uses this value check its validity before using it?

You're right that it can in some way, of course.  But looking at how qpid_hosts is created in [1] a flag to the qpid_hostname argument would be neater than trying to validate it later and retain the use of substitutions, IMO

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator/blob/master/openstack/common/rpc/impl_qpid.py"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-15 05:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

What I'm hearing is "if qpid_hosts contains a bogus broker address, it's hard to debug". The case of qpid_hostname being empty is just one specific case of that. But really, there are a bunch of hard-to-predict ways that qpid_hosts could be bogus and we should handle them all equally by making connection creation errors easier to diagnose.

And also, your point about substitution is important - it is valid for qpid_hostname to be empty if you specify a value for qpid_hosts which doesn't substitute qpid_hostname'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-12 06:15:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add a "not_empty" flag for string options

In bug #1200343 a blank value for the qpid hostname string option was
injected.  This resulted in every service dying in non-obvious ways as
the various RPC layers tried to use a blank hostname.

Picking this up at config time would be better.  Since some strings
may be valid blank values (passwords, etc), this adds a flag for
options such as hostnames to be marked as "not_empty" -- this
indicates they must have some value.

Change-Id: I7784a9368772bbb9bacef03c97446003a42a8b3c
'}, {'created': '2013-07-12 10:22:45.000000000', 'message': 'Add a "not_empty" flag for string options

In bug #1200343 a blank value for the qpid hostname string option was
injected.  This resulted in every service dying in non-obvious ways as
the various RPC layers tried to use a blank hostname.

Picking this up at config time would be better.  Since some strings
may be valid blank values (passwords, etc), this adds a flag for
options such as hostnames to be marked as "not_empty" -- this
indicates they must have some value.

Change-Id: I7784a9368772bbb9bacef03c97446003a42a8b3c
'}]
commit_message:
Add a "not_empty" flag for string options

In bug #1200343 a blank value for the qpid hostname string option was
injected.  This resulted in every service dying in non-obvious ways as
the various RPC layers tried to use a blank hostname.

Picking this up at config time would be better.  Since some strings
may be valid blank values (passwords, etc), this adds a flag for
options such as hostnames to be marked as "not_empty" -- this
indicates they must have some value.

Change-Id: I7784a9368772bbb9bacef03c97446003a42a8b3c

commit_message:
Separate actual service forms from service wizard.

Move all service forms available for selection in Create Service
wizard to separate modules. Such module must implement Service form in
class named 'Form' so the services framework could load them
automatically.

This commit is first in series of 6 commits implementing framework for
dynamic service creation forms.

Change-Id: Ibd0dd378711568fada963f118c0fd16d9a675af9
